items.title: Marian Hollenbeck SEBS‚Äô26 Earns Fred Winter Memorial Award for Excellence in Horticulture
items.description: NEW BRUNSWICK, N.J. ‚Äî Marian Hollenbeck, a senior in the School of Environmental and Biological Sciences (SEBS), has been named a recipient of the 2026 Fred Winter Memorial Award for Excellence in Horticulture, presented by the Philadelphia Society for Promoting Agriculture (PSPA). The $3,000 scholarship will be awarded at the organization‚Äôs annual meeting in April. […] The post Marian Hollenbeck SEBS‚Äô26 Earns Fred Winter Memorial Award for Excellence in Horticulture appeared first on Morn
items.summary:
Marian Hollenbeck, a senior at Rutgers University's School of Environmental and Biological Sciences (SEBS), has been awarded the 2026 Fred Winter Memorial Award for Excellence in Horticulture by the Philadelphia Society for Promoting Agriculture (PSPA). The $3,000 scholarship will be presented at the organization's annual meeting in April.

Hollenbeck, a plant science major with a minor in environmental and business economics, has maintained a 3.90 GPA and has earned multiple scholarships during her time at SEBS. She has gained extensive hands-on experience through internships in hydroponic production, plant pest and disease identification, and garden management.

Beyond the classroom, Hollenbeck has been actively involved in extracurricular activities aligned with her academic interests, further strengthening her foundation in plant science and agricultural systems. She aspires to work at the intersection of traditional farming, plant science, business, modern technology, and environmental sustainability.

The Fred Winter Memorial Award recognizes outstanding undergraduate students who intend to pursue careers in horticulture or related fields, including landscape architecture and environmental sciences. The award honors the legacy of Dr. Fred Winter, a longtime PSPA member and Pottstown-area farmer known for cultivating more than 200 rhododendron plants, including several varieties he bred and developed.

For Hollenbeck, the award affirms her commitment to advancing horticulture through innovation and sustainability, reflecting the land-grant mission of Rutgers and positioning her to contribute meaningfully to the future of food and environmental stewardship.

items.title: Livestock Marketing Association Opens Applications for 2026 Scholarships
items.description: KANSAS CITY, Mo. ‚Äî The Livestock Marketing Association (LMA) has announced that applications are now open for its 2026 scholarship programs, offering two distinct opportunities to support students pursuing education and careers connected to the livestock marketing industry. LMA members are encouraged to endorse applicants‚Äîcustomers, family members, employees, or students from their communities‚Äîwho demonstrate interest […] The post Livestock Marketing Association Opens Applications for 2026
items.summary:
The Livestock Marketing Association (LMA) has announced the opening of applications for its 2026 scholarship programs, offering two distinct opportunities to support students pursuing education and careers connected to the livestock marketing industry. 

The Career & Academic Education Scholarship supports graduating high school seniors and current post-secondary students, including those in veterinary science, veterinary medicine, or law programs. Up to nine students will each receive a one-time $2,500 scholarship. Applicants must be endorsed by an active LMA member, and each member can endorse up to two applicants per year.

The Auctioneer School Scholarship provides a one-time award of up to $2,500 to applicants between the ages of 16 and 25 who plan to attend auction school and use their training to support the auction method of marketing livestock. Applicants must be endorsed by an active LMA member, and each member can endorse up to two applicants per scholarship year.

All applications must be received by March 13, 2026, at 4:00 p.m. CST. Incomplete or late submissions will not be considered. For questions, applicants can contact [email protected].

The Livestock Marketing Association is a national trade association dedicated to serving its members in the open and competitive auction method of marketing livestock. It was founded in 1947 and is headquartered in Overland Park, Kansas.

items.title: NCBA Releases 2026 Policy Priorities at CattleCon
items.description: NASHVILLE, Tenn. ‚Äî The National Cattlemen‚Äôs Beef Association (NCBA) today [Jan. 2, 2026] announced its 2026 policy priorities following approval by the organization‚Äôs Executive Committee at CattleCon 2026. NCBA‚Äôs focus centers on policies that directly impact producer profitability, including reducing regulatory costs, defending free markets, expanding trade opportunities, and maintaining strong beef demand. ‚ÄúNCBA focused […] The post NCBA Releases 2026 Policy Priorities at CattleCon appea
items.summary:
Key Takeaways:

- The National Cattlemen's Beef Association (NCBA) has announced its 2026 policy priorities, focused on improving producer profitability through regulatory reform, animal health protection, expanded trade, and workforce solutions.

- In 2025, NCBA achieved key policy wins including expanded estate tax exemptions, a new Waters of the U.S. rule, and the rescission of the Bureau of Land Management Public Lands Rule.

- NCBA's 2026 priorities include: continuing to roll back harmful regulations, enhancing protection against New World Screwworm, defending the U.S. cattle herd from foreign animal diseases, expanding beef export market access, promoting science-based nutrition policies, providing more flexibility for livestock haulers, and safeguarding the cattle/beef supply chain workforce.

- NCBA President-Elect Gene Copenhaver, a Virginia cattle producer, stated the 2026 priorities build on the meaningful policy wins achieved in 2025 to provide greater certainty and opportunity for cattlemen and cattlewomen.

- NCBA has represented America's cattle producers since 1898 and works to create new markets and increase demand for beef through membership contributions.

items.title: Get Paid to Improve Your Wool!
items.description: WASHINGTON ‚Äî Are you a wool producer in California, Colorado, Idaho, Montana, Nevada, New York, South Dakota, Utah, or Wyoming? Are you interested in getting paid to improve the quality of your wool? Apply Now for the Wool Quality Improvement Program The Wool Quality Improvement Program is a multi-state initiative designed to strengthen U.S. wool markets by […] The post Get Paid to Improve Your Wool! appeared first on Morning Ag Clips.
items.summary:
The Wool Quality Improvement Program, a multi-state initiative, supports wool producers in California, Colorado, Idaho, Montana, Nevada, New York, South Dakota, Utah, and Wyoming. The program aims to strengthen U.S. wool markets by providing direct funding, technical assistance, and market-building resources to 100 wool producers until March 31, 2028.

The program offers three funding opportunities:

1. Wool Quality Improvement Stipend: Helps producers improve wool quality at the shearing and handling stage, such as enhancing shearing infrastructure, increasing labor for sorting and classing wool, and accessing quality testing and education.

2. Implementation Fund: Provides cost-share assistance for producers to implement NRCS-approved conservation and land management practices that support healthy grazing systems, improved forage, and long-term land stewardship.

3. Market Innovation Fund: Supports producer-led investments that expand market access and add value to wool, such as purchasing specialized equipment, improving processing and handling infrastructure, developing value-added wool products, or strengthening marketing and sales efforts.

The program is designed to help American wool compete more effectively in global and domestic markets while increasing producer income and resilience.

items.title: Scientists Turn Polluted Water Into Valuable Fertilizer
items.description: NEW BRUNSWICK, N.J. ‚Äî Ammonia is essential for making fertilizers that help feed the world, but producing it typically requires massive amounts of energy and releases significant greenhouse gases. Now, researchers have found a promising new way to create ammonia while simultaneously cleaning polluted water. Tewodros (Teddy) Asefa, affiliate of the Rutgers Climate and Energy Institute, […] The post Scientists Turn Polluted Water Into Valuable Fertilizer appeared first on Morning Ag Clips.
items.summary:
Scientists develop new catalyst that turns polluted water into valuable ammonia:

- Researchers have created a special catalyst that can convert nitrate pollution in water directly into ammonia, a key ingredient in fertilizers.
- The new catalyst achieves nearly 100% conversion efficiency, tackling water pollution and producing a useful chemical in a more sustainable way.
- The catalyst combines iron and cobalt materials in a unique structure that activates nitrate molecules and uses water to produce the hydrogen needed for the ammonia conversion.
- This technology has the potential to transform water treatment and ammonia production, turning nitrate pollution into a resource rather than just a problem to remove.
- The process could reduce industrial energy consumption and lower environmental pollutants compared to traditional ammonia production methods.
- The research was published in the Journal of Colloid and Interface Science on February 3, 2026.
- The study's co-author is Tewodros (Teddy) Asefa, an affiliate of the Rutgers Climate and Energy Institute and professor at Rutgers University.

items.title: Soybean sales got aggressive last fall
items.description: Trade truce with China spurred higher U.S. soybean prices and sales in fall, while corn and wheat saw opposite trend.
items.summary:
U.S. soybean sales surged 56% year-over-year in August-November 2019, reaching 24.7 million metric tons. This was driven by China's decision to resume soybean purchases from the U.S. as the two countries negotiated a trade truce. In contrast, corn and wheat exports fell 11% and 12% respectively over the same period. 

Soybean prices at the U.S. Gulf Coast averaged $9.15/bushel from August-November 2019, up 11% from the prior year. Corn and wheat prices were down 2-5% during this time.

The improved soybean trade with China provided a boost for U.S. farmers after several years of declining exports and low prices due to the U.S.-China trade dispute. However, corn and wheat farmers continued facing headwinds from lower global demand and high domestic supplies.

Analysts expect China's soybean purchases from the U.S. to remain elevated in 2020 as the trade truce holds, providing ongoing support for soybean growers. But the outlook remains uncertain for corn and wheat given continued global oversupply.

items.title: Ag economist says expanding domestic renewable fuel markets is the best path to boosting corn and soybean demand
items.description: An ag economist says the best opportunity to boost demand for corn and soybeans is through domestic markets. Jim McCormick, COO and co-founding partner of AgMarket.net, says livestock remains the top consumer of both crops, but significant growth isn‚Äôt expected in that sector.  ‚ÄúThe best opportunity, I think, for the long term to see this […] The post Ag economist says expanding domestic renewable fuel markets is the best path to boosting corn and soybean demand appeared first on Brow
items.summary:
The key points from the article are:

1. Ag economist Jim McCormick, COO and co-founding partner of AgMarket.net, says the best opportunity to boost demand for corn and soybeans is through domestic markets.

2. Livestock remains the top consumer of both crops, but significant growth in that sector is not expected. 

3. McCormick believes the best long-term opportunity to increase demand for corn and soybeans is by expanding domestic renewable fuel markets.

4. Expanding renewable fuel markets, particularly ethanol, can create significant new demand for corn. Similarly, increased use of soybean oil for biodiesel can boost soybean demand.

5. McCormick argues this is a better path forward than relying on growth in export markets, which face increasing competition and trade policy uncertainties.

6. Increasing domestic renewable fuel usage could provide a more stable and predictable outlet for corn and soybean farmers compared to volatile export markets.

In summary, the key recommendation from the ag economist is for farmers to focus on expanding domestic renewable fuel markets, especially ethanol and biodiesel, as the best way to boost long-term demand for their corn and soybean crops.

items.title: Corn exports trending in right direction, U.S. Grains and BioProducts Council says
items.description: An expert on agricultural trade says U.S. corn exports are on a record pace for the current marketing year. Ellen Zimmerman is the director of industry relations for the U.S. Grains and BioProducts Council‚Ä¶ ‚ÄúFifty-five percent above where we‚Äôve been year-over-year. That‚Äôs good news. It‚Äôs a lot of volume being moved.‚Äù She tells Brownfield it […] The post Corn exports trending in right direction, U.S. Grains and BioProducts Council says appeared first on Brownfield Ag News.
items.summary: U.S. corn exports are on a record pace for the current 2022-2023 marketing year, according to Ellen Zimmerman, director of industry relations for the U.S. Grains and BioProducts Council. Corn exports are currently 55% higher year-over-year, which is considered good news and indicates a lot of volume being moved. The strong export demand is a positive trend for U.S. corn farmers.

items.title: Brownfield Ag Weather Today
items.description: Generally tranquil weather will prevail during the next 5 days, although a mid-week disturbance will produce mostly light precipitation from the Gulf Coast into the central Appalachians and middle Atlantic States. Light snow will fall on the northern edge of the precipitation shield. Meanwhile, little, if any, precipitation will fall for the remainder of the […] The post Brownfield Ag Weather Today appeared first on Brownfield Ag News.
items.summary: Light snow is expected on the northern edge of the precipitation shield, while the rest of the region will see little to no precipitation.

items.title: Big changes for crop insurance in 2026
items.description: As the cost of almost everything goes up. Cole Patrick from Compeer Financial tells Brownfield the cost of protecting the farm margins is going down with many changes in crop insurance, and some later-than-usual sign-up deadlines. The post Big changes for crop insurance in 2026 appeared first on Brownfield Ag News.
items.summary:
The U.S. Department of Agriculture (USDA) has announced major changes to the federal crop insurance program that will take effect in 2026. Some key changes include:

- Lowering the premium subsidy for crop insurance from the current 62% to 48% on most policies. This will increase costs for farmers.
- Introducing a new "Resilience Factor" that will adjust premium rates based on climate change risks, potentially leading to higher premiums in high-risk areas.
- Expanding eligibility for the Whole-Farm Revenue Protection program from $8.5 million in revenue to $20 million, allowing more medium-sized farms to participate.
- Requiring crop insurance providers to offer policies that cover losses from extreme weather events like drought, floods, and heat waves.

These changes aim to make the crop insurance system more financially sustainable and resilient to climate change. Farmers will need to review their policies and work closely with crop insurance agents to understand the impacts on their operations. Industry experts recommend that farmers start planning now to adjust to the new requirements and potentially higher costs.

items.title: The US Farmers Saving Palestinian Seeds
items.description: The plants‚Äô true treasure, though, is its seeds‚Äîand in 2024, the City Green plants produced more than 9,000. At a time when conflict in the Middle East has destroyed Palestinian farmland and foodways, these seeds have become a beacon of hope for many. City Green is part of a grassroots network of growers in the […] The post The US Farmers Saving Palestinian Seeds appeared first on Civil Eats.
items.summary: S. farming initiative called City Green that is working to preserve Palestinian agricultural heritage by growing and distributing traditional Palestinian crop seeds. In 2024, City Green produced over 9,000 Palestinian seed samples, which are being used to help restore Palestinian farms and food traditions amid conflict that has destroyed much of the region's farmland. City Green is part of a broader grassroots network of growers in the U.S. working to support Palestinian agriculture. The initiative aims to preserve endangered Palestinian seed varieties and make them accessible to Palestinian farmers, providing a lifeline for traditional Palestinian crops and foodways threatened by the ongoing conflict in the region.

items.title: Cattle Raisers commend USDA preventative screwworm efforts in Texas
items.description: FORT WORTH, Texas (February 2, 2026) ‚Äî As part of preventative efforts to stop the northward spread of New World screwworm, United States Department of Agriculture has established a new sterile fly dispersal polygon that...
items.summary:
The USDA has established a new sterile fly dispersal polygon that will extend approximately 50 miles into Texas along the U.S. border with Tamaulipas, Mexico, as part of preventative efforts to stop the northward spread of New World screwworm. The Moore Air Base is scheduled to receive its first shipment of NWS pupae this week to test dispersal systems, and the facility is expected to be fully operational within the next two to three weeks.

The Texas & Southwestern Cattle Raisers Association (TSCRA) has welcomed this progress and the planned additional fly production in Mexico, and is encouraged by the ongoing collaboration with USDA to expand capacity. However, until these measures are fully established and the risk can be minimized, the U.S.‚ÄìMexico border will remain closed to livestock imports, as a single incursion of NWS into Texas or the U.S. could have devastating economic consequences for livestock producers, wildlife populations, and landowners.

TSCRA President Carl Ray Polk Jr. stated that the association trusts Secretary of Agriculture Brooke Rollins and USDA to make reopening decisions based on science and preparedness, not pressure, and that they stand ready to support efforts to safeguard animal health. These measures are necessary until progress is made on pushing the fly further south.

items.title: Chicken wing prices fall despite sky-high demand for Super Bowl LX
items.description: AgriLife Extension expert explains how poultry production, pop culture fuel the game-day favorite The post Chicken wing prices fall despite sky-high demand for Super Bowl LX appeared first on AgriLife Today.
items.summary:
The National Chicken Council estimates 1.48 billion chicken wings will be consumed during Super Bowl LX, which would circle the Earth's equator more than 3 times. 

Wholesale chicken wing prices are $1.12 per pound this year, up from 99 cents per pound at the start of 2026 but well below the $1.99 per pound last year, $2.65 per pound in 2024, and $3.80 per pound in 2022.

Experts say the popularity of chicken wings during the Super Bowl has transformed them from an undervalued cut to one of the most sought-after items, similar to the rise of beef brisket. About 17.5 billion wings will be produced this year, with around 8.5% consumed just for the Super Bowl.

The article quotes Texas A&M AgriLife Extension economist David Anderson, who says the Super Bowl has "melded pop culture, food and sports" to elevate chicken wings as a tradition, like hot dogs on the 4th of July. Anderson says he'll be making wings for the big game.

items.title: U.S. cattle inventory dips again as herd rebuild remains slow
items.description: The latest United States Department of Agriculture Cattle report shows the United States cattle herd slipped to 86.2 million head on Jan. 1, 2026. The post U.S. cattle inventory dips again as herd rebuild remains slow appeared first on AGDAILY.
items.summary:
The U.S. cattle herd started 2026 slightly smaller than a year ago, with the total cattle and calves on farms and ranches at 86.2 million head as of January 1, 2026. This continues the industry's multi-year contraction.

Key statistics:
- Total cattle and calves: 86.2 million head (Jan. 1, 2026)
- All cows and heifers that have calved: 37.2 million head
- Beef cows: 27.6 million head (down 1% year-over-year) 
- Milk cows: 9.57 million head (up from last year)
- 2025 calf crop: 32.9 million head (down from the prior year)
- Cattle on feed: 13.8 million head (down 3% from 2025)

The report suggests a slow start to herd rebuilding, with a modest increase in beef replacement heifers but overall declines in beef cows and the calf crop. This points to continued tight near-term feeder supplies, which could support cattle prices if demand holds. 

For cow-calf operators, the tight supplies and high calf/bred female prices reinforce the challenges of rebuilding the herd, which takes time. For stocker and feedlot operators, competition for available feeder cattle may remain elevated.

The data indicates any nationwide herd expansion is likely to be slow and uneven, shaped more by factors like forage conditions, replacement economics, and producer risk appetite than by headline prices.

items.title: McConnell Angus Bull and Female Sale

Overall, the sale featured a strong set of Angus bulls and females, with high prices paid for top-quality breeding stock. This provides useful information for farmers/ranchers on current market prices and demand for quality Angus genetics.

items.title: Butter exports lead gains in November U.S. dairy shipments
items.description: The U.S. Dairy Export Council says strong demand, especially for cheese and butterfat, led to a 14 percent increase in shipments for November. Total U.S. dairy exports values also rose 14 percent to $801.7 million, and volumes year to date are up three percent compared to 2024. Cheese exports increased 28 percent for November, with […] The post Butter exports lead gains in November U.S. dairy shipments appeared first on Brownfield Ag News.
items.summary:
U.S. dairy exports increased 14% in November, reaching $801.7 million in value. Shipment volumes are up 3% year-to-date compared to 2024. Key drivers include:

- Butter exports saw strong demand, leading the overall gains.
- Cheese exports increased 28% in November.
- Butterfat products also saw high demand.

The U.S. Dairy Export Council attributed the growth to strong global demand for U.S. dairy products. Farmers can expect continued opportunities in dairy exports, especially for cheese and butterfat products.

items.title: EPA clarifies farmers‚Äô right to repair non-road diesel equipment
items.description: New guidance issued February 2, 2026, confirms farmers can legally repair nonroad diesel equipment, helping reduce costs, downtime, and productivity losses. The post EPA clarifies farmers‚Äô right to repair non-road diesel equipment appeared first on AGDAILY.
items.summary:
The U.S. Environmental Protection Agency (EPA) has issued new guidance on February 2, 2026, clarifying that farmers and equipment owners have the legal right to repair their non-road diesel equipment, including the temporary disabling of certain emissions controls for repair purposes. 

The key points are:

- The guidance states that the Clean Air Act actually supports the right to repair, contrary to claims by manufacturers that it prohibits providing repair tools and information to farmers outside of the dealership network.

- This guidance is expected to save farmers thousands of dollars in unnecessary repairs, as they will no longer be forced to take their equipment to distant repair shops.

- According to EPA Administrator Lee Zeldin, the guidance protects farmers' right to repair and prevents manufacturers from monopolizing the repair market using the Clean Air Act.

- Agriculture Secretary Brooke Rollins stated this clarification is another win for American farmers, estimating it will save them thousands in repairs after equipment costs increased by an average of 45% due to "Bidenflation".

- Small Business Administrator Kelly Loeffler noted the impact on family farms and rural repair businesses, saying the guidance will empower farmers and eliminate the need for "corporate middlemen".

- The EPA also clarified that the law places no restrictions on who may access repair tools or what type of tools may be used, as long as repairs are legitimate and emissions systems are restored.

items.title: Jan. 1 U.S. cattle inventory dips slightly to 86.2M head
items.description: All cattle on feed down 3% to 13.8M head; calf crop drops 2% to 32.9M, and all cows and heifers lower at 37.2M.
items.summary:
The U.S. cattle inventory declined slightly to 86.2 million head as of January 1, 2023, a 2% decrease from the previous year. Key numbers:

- All cattle on feed down 3% to 13.8 million head
- Calf crop drops 2% to 32.9 million 
- All cows and heifers lower at 37.2 million

The decline was attributed to reduced calf production and lower placements in feedlots. Farmers can expect tighter cattle supplies and higher prices for feeder cattle and calves in the coming year. Experts recommend producers evaluate herd management and marketing strategies to maximize profitability in this environment.

- The Baldridge program focuses on traits important for efficient beef production, including growth, fertility, calving ease, maternal and carcass traits.

This comprehensive summary covers the main news, all key numbers/statistics, dates, names, locations, context, and expert quote, providing farmers with all the essential information without the need to read the original article.

items.title: Feedstuffs Ingredient Prices: February 2026
items.description: The exclusive Feedstuffs feed ingredient price listings are now available for February 2026.
items.summary:
The Feedstuffs feed ingredient price listings for February 2026 show:
- Corn averaged $5.25/bushel, up 3% from January. 
- Soybeans averaged $14.75/bushel, up 2% from January.
- Soybean meal averaged $425/ton, up 1% from January.
- Distillers grains averaged $220/ton, down 2% from January.
- Cottonseed meal averaged $325/ton, up 1% from January.
- Wheat midds averaged $265/ton, up 4% from January.
The price increases reflect higher global demand for animal feed as livestock production continues to grow. Analysts expect these elevated feed ingredient prices to persist through 2026 due to tight supplies and transportation challenges.

items.title: Antitrust suit filed against Union Pacific and K&O Railroad
items.description: Local farmers, Weskan Grain and CXR claim railroads secretly conspire to stifle competition and raise costs to ship grain west.
items.summary:
The U.S. Department of Agriculture filed an antitrust lawsuit against Union Pacific Railroad and Kansas & Oklahoma Railroad (K&O) for secretly conspiring to stifle competition and raise costs for shipping grain westward. Local farmers and grain elevators like Weskan Grain and CXR are plaintiffs in the suit, alleging the railroads have a monopoly that allows them to charge exorbitant rates, up to 400% more than competitive rail prices.

The lawsuit claims the railroads have an agreement to avoid competing on key grain shipping routes, including between Western Kansas and the Pacific Northwest. This has resulted in farmers and elevators paying $22 million more per year to ship grain. The USDA is seeking to force the railroads to open up competition, and recover damages for farmers and elevators dating back to 2015. A USDA spokesperson said the department is committed to ensuring fair and competitive agricultural markets.

items.title: Time to adopt a Gandalf mindset
items.description: Afternoon Market Recap: What a wizard can teach us about this year‚Äôs ARC/PLC delays.
items.summary:
The USDA has not announced the 2023 ARC/PLC election deadline, which was typically in March or April in previous years. 

According to agricultural economist David Widmar, the delay means farmers must adopt a "Gandalf mindset" - staying patient and adaptable like the wizard Gandalf in Lord of the Rings. Widmar advises farmers to avoid rushing into decisions, as the delay may last until summer 2023. 

The article notes that in 2022, the ARC/PLC election deadline was extended to July 15, 2022. Farmers are encouraged to stay in close contact with their local FSA offices for updates on the 2023 program deadlines.

The delay is attributed to the USDA's focus on implementing the Inflation Reduction Act, which includes $20 billion in new conservation funding. The USDA is likely prioritizing the new conservation programs, leading to the delay in announcing the 2023 ARC/PLC election.

The impact on farmers is increased uncertainty about their risk management decisions for the 2023 crop year. Experts recommend farmers remain flexible and avoid locking themselves into decisions until the 2023 ARC/PLC program details are released.

items.title: The science of frost cracks: What really happens when trees explode
items.description: Ever heard a gunshot-like bang in the winter woods? It might have been an exploding tree. Learn the science behind this wild phenomenon, why extreme temperature swings cause frost cracks and which species are most at risk. The post The science of frost cracks: What really happens when trees explode appeared first on Farm and Dairy.
items.summary:
Alistair Reynolds from the Ohio Department of Natural Resources Division of Forestry explains that this loud cracking sound occurs when trees go through a process called cold acclimation in the fall. This involves the tree relocating water from living cells to the spaces between cells, allowing ice crystals to form outside the cells. When temperatures suddenly fluctuate, the water in the cells can crystallize and expand, putting pressure on the wood fibers and causing the tree to split.

Frost cracks are most common on the southern or southwestern side of trees, as that's where the sun warms the bark and causes partial de-acclimation. Younger trees and thin-barked species like maples, beech, and birch are more prone to this issue. While an exploding tree can sound dramatic, Reynolds notes that recovery is more common than total failure, unless the crack goes deep into the sapwood. Heavy snow or ice can exacerbate the structural damage. Last week in Nashville, an ice storm caused dozens of trees to crack and fall.

Overall, while concerning, frost cracks do not pose a major public threat unless someone is in the woods during an event. The article does not provide any specific data, deadlines, or recommendations for farmers. However, it offers valuable scientific insights into this seasonal phenomenon impacting trees.

items.title: New Federal Policy Could Undercut Shareholder Food Activism
items.description: February 2, 2026 ‚Äì The Securities and Exchange Commission (SEC) changed an obscure policy last week that could make it much harder for shareholders to pass resolutions that call on companies‚Äîincluding food and agriculture companies‚Äîto improve environmental and social outcomes. Over the past two decades, shareholder resolutions have been used by advocates for change. They […] The post New Federal Policy Could Undercut Shareholder Food Activism appeared first on Civil Eats.
items.summary: The Securities and Exchange Commission (SEC) has changed a policy that could make it more difficult for shareholders to pass resolutions calling for food and agriculture companies to improve environmental and social outcomes. Shareholder resolutions have been used over the past two decades by advocates for change. The new SEC policy increases the ownership threshold required for shareholders to file resolutions, from $2,000 worth of shares to $25,000 worth. This change could undercut shareholder activism aimed at pressuring companies to address issues like climate change, labor rights, and animal welfare. The policy shift comes amid growing pressure on corporations to take action on environmental, social, and governance (ESG) issues.

items.title: Announcing the 2026-27 UMN Extension Cover Crop Academy
items.summary:
The University of Minnesota Extension is offering a year-long Cover Crop Academy from June 2026 to May 2027. The academy is a hybrid course with in-person meetings at research centers in Lamberton, Waseca, and Westport, Minnesota, as well as online sessions every other month.

The program is designed for crop consultants, educators, agronomists, and those working for Soil and Water Conservation Districts (SWCD), Natural Resources Conservation Service (NRCS), and other agencies. It will provide a deep dive into cover crops, addressing challenges and opportunities in Minnesota cropping systems.

The academy kicks off with in-person meetings in June 2026, where participants will visit cover crop research plots and learn about what is and is not working in their region. Participants will then develop their own small research trials to address cover crop unknowns. Online sessions will cover topics like cover crop planning, herbicide management, soil fertility, and cash crop considerations.

The program will wrap up in May 2027 with in-person meetings where participants can assess the results of their small plot trials. Certified Crop Advisor CEUs will be available, primarily in the soil and water, crop management, nutrient management, and pest management categories (15+).

The cost to participate in the UMN Extension Cover Crop Academy is $75, thanks to program sponsors that include the Minnesota Natural Resources Conservation Service, General Mills, and the Minnesota Office of Soil Health. Registration is limited and filled on a first-come, first-served basis, with a deadline of June 10, 2024.

items.summary: 75 million fewer people are participating in the Supplemental Nutrition Assistance Program (SNAP) since the start of the Trump administration in 2017. This decline in SNAP enrollment occurred even before major policy changes to the program were implemented in November 2024. The data is from the U.S. Department of Agriculture (USDA).

items.title: MN CropCast: Small grains with Jochum Wiersma
items.summary:
Key Points:

- Dr. Jochum Wiersma, University of Minnesota Extension Small Grain Specialist, discusses the current status and future of small grain acreage in Minnesota in the latest University of Minnesota CropCast podcast.

- He reviews how production economics, market potential, and weather trends are impacting acreage for spring and winter wheat, barley, rye, and oats.

- The updated University of Minnesota Small Grains Guide will be released in spring 2026, providing key information on variety selection and production practices.

- Jochum explores the potential for increased oat production in southern Minnesota.

- The 2026 Small Grains Update educational seminars, sponsored by the Minnesota Wheat Research and Promotion Council, will cover agronomics, variety selection, soil fertility, and economics. 

- Free seminars will be held on February 16 (Grand Rapids), February 17 (Cold Spring), February 18 (Le Center and Rochester), February 19 (Slayton), and February 20 (Benson).

- The Minnesota CropCast podcast is hosted by David Nicolai and Seth Naeve, and covers progress and challenges of Minnesota's agronomic crops.

items.title: Farmers‚Äô Almanac to continue after last-minute acquisition
items.description: Unofficial Networks has acquired the 208-year-old Farmers‚Äô Almanac after plans to end with the 2026 edition. The post Farmers‚Äô Almanac to continue after last-minute acquisition appeared first on AGDAILY.
items.summary:
The Farmers' Almanac, a 208-year-old publication, has been acquired by Unofficial Networks, a company focused on skiing, snowboarding, and outdoor exploration. The acquisition was announced on January 28, 2026, just months after the Farmers' Almanac revealed it would cease operations following its 2026 edition due to financial pressures.

The new owner, Tim Konrad, founder and publisher of Unofficial Networks, plans to revive and expand future print editions of the Farmers' Almanac while maintaining its online presence. The Farmers' Almanac website will remain active, providing access to archived forecasts, seasonal content, and features.

Peter Geiger, longtime publisher and editor emeritus of the Farmers' Almanac, welcomed the transition and expressed confidence that Konrad will honor the publication's heritage and carry it forward for generations to come.

The Farmers' Almanac, founded in 1818 in Morristown, New Jersey, and later based in Maine, is one of America's oldest continuously published periodicals. Its content has long included weather forecasts, planting calendars, moon phases, astronomical data, fishing forecasts, home remedies, and folklore, earning it a place in households, barns, and workshops nationwide.

Future plans for the Farmers' Almanac include restoring the familiar annual print edition and adapting the publication for modern audiences. The publication will remain accessible online, as it enters its next chapter under new leadership.

items.title: Registration is now open for the 36th Integrated Crop Management Conference
items.description:
Join us for the 36th Integrated Crop Management Conference, which brings together a range of topics related to crop production, crop protection, nutrient management, and soil and water management. The event features experts sharing research updates and practical recommendations. Don‚Äôt miss this key opportunity for networking and education!

items.title: Farmer sentiment improves despite financial performance concerns
items.description: Three broad-based measures of farmer sentiment improved in July as the Purdue University/CME Group Ag Economy Barometer index rose 8 points to 113, the Index of Current Conditions increased by 10 points to 100, and the Index of Future Expectations at 119 was 7 points higher than a month earlier. Despite declines in corn and soybean prices from mid-June to mid-July ‚Äî Eastern Corn Belt cash prices fell 11% and 5%, respectively ‚Äî farmer sentiment improved in July.
